 Correct the following sentence to AP style and explain each change: “The Company announced Five new positions in the U.S. Government on Monday.”
model_output: The corrected sentence in AP style is: “The company announced five new positions in the United States government Monday.” Changes include: lowercase “company” because it is not a proper noun, “five” spelled out as a number at the beginning or within text, “United States” spelled out in full and capitalized, “government” lowercase as it is a common noun, and “Monday” capitalized but without “on,” as AP style omits the preposition when the day is used alone [Source: https://www.apstylebook.com/ap_stylebook/checklist-for-self-editing-and-for-reporting-and-writing].

question: What is AP style’s guidance on titles like “Dr.” for medical vs. academic contexts?
model_output: AP Style recommends using "Dr." in a formal title before the name of an individual who holds a medical or dental degree, such as Dr. Jonas Salk, and applying "Dr." or "Drs." in first-reference uses before a name, including direct quotations [Source: https://www.apstylebook.com/ap_stylebook/doctor]. Additionally, AP Style advises capitalizing and spelling out formal titles like chancellor or chair when they precede a name, but lowercase them elsewhere, including modifiers such as department in department chair [Source: https://www.apstylebook.com/ap_stylebook/academic-titles].

question: AP style once discouraged “they” as a singular pronoun. What is the current guidance?
model_output: AP Style now recognizes the use of “they” as a singular pronoun, especially for gender-neutral references. It is included in the 2017 AP Stylebook, which will also be in the upcoming print edition. AP uses “they/them/their” as a way to accurately describe and represent individuals who use those pronouns, despite acknowledging that “they” as a singular pronoun may be confusing for some readers. Balancing clarity and respect for subjects is emphasized in the guidance [Source: https://www.apstylebook.com/ap_stylebook/pronouns][Source: https://www.apstylebook.com/blog_posts/7].

Balancing clarity and respect for subjects is emphasized in the guidance [Source: https://www.apstylebook.com/ap_stylebook/pronouns][Source: https://www.apstylebook.com/blog_posts/7].

“Dr. Jane Smith, a Professor at the University, said Twenty-Five percent of Americans use social media everyday.”
model_output:
Edited paragraph in AP style:
"Dr. Jane Smith, a professor at the University, said 25% of Americans use social media every day."

Five rule applications:
1. The doctor’s title "Dr." is correct as it is; abbreviations are acceptable in AP style (though sometimes spelled out).  
2. "Professor" is lowercase because it is used as a general title before a name; here, since the name is not used, it could remain lowercase.  
3. "University" is lowercase unless part of a formal name, which is not specified here.  
4. The number "Twenty-Five" is replaced with "25" — AP style spells out numbers under 100 only in certain contexts, but consistent use prefers numerals for percentages.  
5. "Everyday" is corrected to "every day" (two words) because in AP style, "every day" (two words) is the correct form when meaning "each day," whereas "everyday" (one word) is an adjective meaning "common" or "ordinary" — the context here calls for "every day" [Source: https://www.apstylebook.com/ap_stylebook/technology-2].
